DataElement.preferredDefinition: The plasma cell myeloma ISS stage.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A bone marrow-based plasma cell neoplasm characterized by a serum monoclonal protein and skeletal destruction with osteolytic lesions, pathological fractures, bone pain, hypercalcemia, and anemia.  Clinical variants include non-secretory myeloma, smoldering myeloma, indolent myeloma, and plasma cell leukemia. (WHO, 2001)_The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A bone marrow-based plasma cell neoplasm characterized by a serum monoclonal protein and skeletal destruction with osteolytic lesions, pathological fractures, bone pain, hypercalcemia, and anemia.  Clinical variants include non-secretory myeloma, smoldering myeloma, indolent myeloma, and plasma cell leukemia. (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

Concepts.definition: A bone marrow-based plasma cell neoplasm characterized by a serum monoclonal protein and skeletal destruction with osteolytic lesions, pathological fractures, bone pain, hypercalcemia, and anemia.  Clinical variants include non-secretory myeloma, smoldering myeloma, indolent myeloma, and plasma cell leukemia. (WHO, 2001)

Property.preferredDefinition: The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: The extent of a cancer in the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A method of staging myeloma published by the International Myeloma Working Group in 2003._The extent of a cancer in the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: ISS Stage I Plasma Cell Myeloma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Plasma cell myeloma with beta-2-microglobulin less than 3.5 and albumin greater than or equal to 3.5 (median survival of 62 months).  Note that the older Durie/Salmon staging system defines stage I quite differently. (PDQ)

Concepts.definition: Multiple myeloma with beta-2-microglobulin less than 3.5 and albumin greater than or equal to 3.5 (median survival of 62 months).  Note that the older Durie/Salmon staging system defines stage I quite differently. (PDQ)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: ISS Stage II Plasma Cell Myeloma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Plasma cell myeloma with beta-2-microglobulin less than 3.5 and albumin less than 3.5 or beta-2-microglobulin 3.5 to less than 5.5 (median survival of 44 months).  Note that the older Durie/Salmon staging system defines stage II quite differently. (PDQ)

Concepts.definition: Multiple myeloma with blood levels of beta-2-microglobulin between 3.5 and 5.5 mg/L.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: ISS Stage III Plasma Cell Myeloma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Plasma cell myeloma with beta-2-microglobulin greater than or equal to 5.5 (median survival of 29 months).  Note that the older Durie/Salmon staging system defines stage III quite differently. (PDQ)

Concepts.definition: Multiple myeloma with beta-2-microglobulin greater than or equal to 5.5 (median survival of 29 months).  Note that the older Durie/Salmon staging system defines stage III quite differently. (PDQ)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: International Staging System for Myeloma Stage
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A method of staging myeloma published by the International Myeloma Working Group in 2003.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A method of staging myeloma published by the International Myeloma Working Group in 2003.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
